Graphical abstract Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts showed high syngas production driven by UV light. The high activity is owing to its high conduction band level and oxygen ion availability. The conversion of methane and carbon dioxide into syngas (dry reforming of methane; DRM) has attracted attention owing to the potential to reuse greenhouse gases. Titanium dioxide (TiO2)-based photocatalysts, which have been widely commercialized owing to their high efficiency, non-toxicity, and low cost, are strongly desired in DRM. Here, we report a monoclinic-phase TiO2-B nanobelts-supported rhodium (Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts) catalyst that efficiently promotes DRM under ultraviolet light irradiation at low temperatures. Photogenerated holes in the TiO2-B nanobelts were used to oxidize methane, while the electrons were trapped in rhodium to reduce carbon dioxide. Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts exhibited considerably higher durability and activity than Rh-loaded conventional TiO2 (anatase and rutile), owing to the lattice and/or surface oxygen reactivity in TiO2-B nanobelts, which was suggested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements and photocatalytic performance tests under an atmosphere of methane alone. This study paves the path for the effective utilization of methane by constructing active TiO2-based nanometal photocatalysts. Keywords Photocatalysis Dry reforming of methane Greenhouse gas conversion Gas-phase reaction Titanium dioxide TiO2-B 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM) converts methane and carbon dioxide, identified as contributors to the greenhouse effect [1], to syngas (hydrogen and carbon monoxide) with a H2/CO molar ratio of 1 [2]. As a result, this process has the potential to mitigate the environmental challenges associated with greenhouse gas emissions and to convert natural gas (hydrate), shale gas, biogas, and carbon dioxide captured by the current development of the carbon capture and storage strategy to syngas [2–10]. The reaction governing DRM is CH4 + CO2 = 2CO + 2H2 (ΔH 298K = +247 kJ mol−1). As an extremely endothermic reaction, DRM usually requires high operating temperatures, usually in the range of 900–1273 K, to achieve the desired conversion levels [2,10]. The forward reaction is favored at low pressures, as dictated by Le Chatelier's principle. Moreover, it has been noticed that a CO2/CH4 molar ratio higher than the stoichiometric requirement of 1 can also lead to high syngas yields [11,12]. Despite the considerable environmental potential of DRM, this reaction is not considered an industrially mature process. The extremely high endothermic reaction, coupled with rapid carbon formation (so-called coking) as a side reaction eventually leads to catalyst deactivation and/or damage to the reactor. To solve these problems, the utilization of photon energy is a potential method because the photocatalytic reaction occurs at low temperatures beyond the thermodynamic limit. The effective use of photon energy through photocatalysts has been studied in various fields, such as water splitting and CO2 reduction, since the reaction was discovered in 1972 [13–20]. In recent years, the use of photon energy to drive DRM reactions has attracted attention and has been studied [21–34]. Yuliati et al. employed a Ga2O3 photocatalyst for the conversion of methane and CO2 to syngas at mild temperatures, such as 473 K [21]. In addition to this report, various arguments regarding the reaction mechanism of photo-assisted DRM reactions have been discussed. Several studies have suggested that plasmonic metal nanoparticle catalysts can be used to accelerate DRM [22,23]. Djinović et al. reported Ni/CeO2− x catalyst, which contains partly reduced Ce3+ sites crucial for extending the optical absorption, converts CH4 and CO2 in two photocatalytic mechanisms: the hot charge-carrier driven photocatalytic mechanism and the near-field induced resonant energy transfer, depending on the energy of photons used to stimulate the catalyst [24]. In addition, photo-thermochemical DRM was reported by Pan et al. to produce syngas using concentrated sunlight as the energy input [25]. In contrast to the plasmonic excitation of metals and the photothermal effect, several studies have reported a photocatalytic DRM reaction using interband transitions in metal oxide semiconductors [26,27,33,34]. Amin et al. achieved an efficient bi-reforming of methane over Ag- and La-loaded protonated g-C3N4 nanotubes [26]. The loaded Ag interacts strongly with both protonated g-C3N4 nanotubes and La, which is advantageous for the dynamic transfer of photogenerated electrons from protonated g-C3N4 nanotubes to Ag. Recently, Shoji et al. reported that rhodium-loaded strontium titanate (Rh/SrTiO3) considerably exceeded the theoretical thermodynamic limit, indicating the potential use of photocatalysis to be industrialized and used for DRM to help the procedure of a thermodynamically disadvantageous reaction under mild reaction conditions [27]. In their report, Rh/SnO2 and Rh/WO3 poorly promoted DRM under light irradiation because the CO2 reduction, which is one of the major reaction pathways comprising DRM, hardly occurs due to its low conduction band position. Furthermore, in their report, the photocatalysts with a high activity for DRM were strontium titanate, zirconium oxide, and tantalum oxide; compared to these, the activity of titanium dioxide (TiO2) was not as high. TiO2 has attracted considerable attention for various applications such as photocatalysis, dye-sensitized solar cells, sensor devices, pigments, cosmetics, and protective coatings. In particular, TiO2 is the most studied photocatalyst because of its high efficiency, non-toxicity, chemical and biological stability, and low cost [35–37]. Ultraviolet (UV) irradiation can generate electrons and holes in TiO2, which are good reductants and powerful oxidants for redox reactions. Although the use of TiO2 in methane/carbon dioxide mixing systems has been studied, a significant conversion at low temperatures has not been achieved yet. László et al. used titanate nanotubes modified with gold or rhodium nanoparticles, and approximately 3% methane conversion (production rate of H2 = 104 µmol h−1 g−1) was achieved in the best cases. In this previous report, the photocatalyst was modified with gold particles with controlled particle size; however, the carbon dioxide conversion was not traceable [38]. Tahir et al. reported the highest performance of DRM under UV light irradiation (production rate of H2 = 1126 µmol h−1 g−1) based on TiO2 catalysts modified with nickel and montmorillonite using fixed-bed and monolith photoreactors [39]. Improved DRM activities using TiO2-based materials are expected for industrial applications. In the present study, we focused on the monoclinic TiO2-B crystal, which is a different polymorph from well-known rutile, anatase, and brookite. Based on previous photocatalytic DRM studies, there are three requirements for semiconductors to achieve a high activity in photocatalytic DRM reactions, that is, a high conduction band level for carbon dioxide reduction, oxygen ion activation for the efficient mediator, and high surface area with high crystallinity [27,40]. Among the various crystal polymorphs of TiO2, TiO2-B nanobelts meet these three requirements. First, TiO2-B has been reported to have a higher conduction band level than anatase-type TiO2 [41,42]. Lo et al. reported that TiO2-B has a 0.14 eV higher than that of anatase-type TiO2 [42]. Second, the inclusion of Ti3+ defects and oxygen defects [42,43] facilitates the activation of oxygen ions. Indeed, TiO2-B is used as an anode for rechargeable lithium batteries and negative electrodes for supercapacitors because of its high capacity for lithium-ion intercalation and high rate capability [44,45]. Third, TiO2-B has a unique nanobelt structure with a high surface area, and its nano-sized structure shortens the diffusion distance of oxygen ions as well as excited charge carriers for transporting them to reactants. In this study, TiO2-B nanobelts were synthesized by crystallization of protonated titanate, which was obtained by hydrothermal treatment of anatase TiO2 in a concentrated sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution [46,47]. Crystallization from protonated titanate to TiO2-B nanobelts was conducted by UV light irradiation under DRM conditions after loading the rhodium cocatalyst precursor onto protonate titanate. We compared the photocatalytic DRM activities of rhodium-loaded TiO2-B (Rh/TiO2-B) with those of rhodium-loaded rutile and anatase TiO2. We also discuss the reason for the efficient photocatalytic DRM activity of Rh/TiO2-B by various spectroscopic analyses. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysis preparation Titanate nanobelts were synthesized by adding anatase-type TiO2 powder (Ishihara Sangyo, ST-01) to a 10 mol dm−3 aqueous solution of NaOH. After stirring for several hours, the resulting suspension was transferred to a polytetrafluoroethylene-lined autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 168 h. The product was acid-washed, and the sample remained in 0.05 mol dm−3 HCl solution for 2 h. The material was then filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at 80 °C for over 24 h. Metal rhodium nanoparticles were supported on acid-washed titanate nanobelts by photo-deposition to obtain supported metal photocatalysts. In other words, Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts were fabricated by crystallization of protonated titanate loaded with rhodium precursor by UV light irradiation under DRM conditions (in situ photo-DRM process). As a typical in-situ photo-DRM process, 500 mg of titanate was suspended in 3.2 mL of methanol in a glass reactor with a flat bottom window for light irradiation, followed by the addition of rhodium chloride hydrous (Kanto Chemical) aqueous solution, where the amount of rhodium atom was set to 0.1–10 wt% versus titanate nanobelts. After studying the dependence on rhodium loading, the procedure was fixed at adding 0.8 mL of rhodium chloride hydrous (denoted as RhCl3∙3H2O) aqueous solution (0.1 mmol of Rh). The suspension was irradiated with a 150 W Hg − Xe lamp (Hayashi-Repic, LA-410UV-5) for 15 min after nitrogen bubbling for 15 min. After photoirradiation, the suspension was filtered, and the residual powder was washed with distilled water, followed by drying at 80 °C. After drying, the powder samples were illuminated by a Hg–Xe lamp under in situ DRM conditions (CH4: CO2: Ar = 1: 1: 98 vol%) at 150 °C, and then the photocatalyst support was crystallized into TiO2-B nanobelts. For comparison, we also synthesized Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts through the following two-step process: protonated titanate was annealed to crystallize it into TiO2-B nanobelts, after which Rh nanoparticles were loaded onto them by the photodeposition method. Commercial strontium titanate (FUJIFILM Wako), rutile-type TiO2 (Kanto Chemical), and TiO2 P25 (Evonik) were used as the control samples, each loaded with rhodium by photodeposition in the same manner as described above. 2.2 Characterization The elemental analysis of the Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts samples for individual elements was performed using ICP-OES (Agilent, 5100 ICP-OES). The surface areas of the samples were measured at 77 K using a BET method (Shimadzu, Tristar II 3020 Micromeritics). The crystal structures of the samples were analyzed using XRD (Rigaku, SmartLab) with Cu Kα radiation. The surface morphologies of the materials were observed using an SEM (Hitachi, FE-SEM SU9000) operated at 30 kV and TEM (JEOL, JEM-2010F) operated at 200 kV. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded by a diffuse reflection method using a spectrophotometer (JASCO, V-670). XPS (ULVAC-PHI, PHI5000 VersaProbe) with an Al Kα radiation source (1486.7 eV) was used to analyze the elemental states of the samples. All binding energies were calibrated using the C 1s peak (BE = 284.8 eV) as a standard. The photoexcited species were evaluated by operando ESR (Bruker, EMX-nano) at 90 K under a nitrogen atmosphere. 2.3 Evaluation of photocatalytic dry reforming of methane The photocatalytic activities of the powder samples were measured under ambient pressure in a flow reactor with a quartz window, which enabled us to irradiate the powder samples with a 150 W Hg–Xe lamp (Hayashi-Repic, LA-410UV-5). We examined photocatalytic water splitting, which is a proton-mediated reaction, to compare with the DRM reaction, which is a gas-phase reaction with oxygen ions as the mediator. The generated products of hydrogen were measured from analysis of the headspace gas by the GC-TCD (GC = gas chromatography, TCD = thermal conductivity detector). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Photocatalysis characterization Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts were fabricated by crystallization of protonated titanate loaded with rhodium precursor by UV light irradiation under DRM conditions (in situ photo-DRM process). Regardless of the unfavorable conditions, the yield of hydrogen under UV light irradiation conditions was 8.3 times higher than that under dark conditions, as shown in Fig. 7(a). As indicated by the red dots in Fig. S11, the DRM was driven over a relative light intensity I/I 0 of 0.5 or more. If a reaction proceeds by photocatalysis under light-limited conditions without any thermal process, this relationship follows a linear line passing through zero. However, the present result implies that there is an activation step other than the absorbed photon numbers, particularly under low light intensity conditions. Similar to our previous study, the present efficient DRM reaction is driven by the photocatalysis process, that is, the photoexcited electron-hole pairs that are generated in the metal oxide semiconductor, and the electrons are injected into the Rh nanoparticles to reduce CO2, while the holes in the valence band of the metal oxide semiconductor react with methane [27,40]. To confirm this reaction mechanism, electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were performed (Fig. S14). In this figure, the orange line shows the ESR spectrum of bare TiO2-B nanobelts (without Rh) under dark conditions in a nitrogen atmosphere, and two signals are observed. The first is an oxygen defect peak with a g value of approximately 2.00 [53,54], which does not disappear even after Rh loading (gray line in Fig. S14 in the supporting information). The second peak appears at a g value of approximately 1.96 and can be assigned to Ti3+ defects [53,54]. The signal intensity of Ti3+ increased with UV irradiation (green line in Fig. S14), indicating the generation of photoexcited electrons at the conduction band (titanium 3d orbital), that is, trapped electrons at Ti4+ sites creating Ti3+ species. In contrast, the signal appearing between g values of 2.00 and 2.03, particularly observed under UV irradiation was identified as an oxygen radical (O-•) species [53], which was observed as a photoexcited hole excited at the valence band (oxygen 2p orbital). Trapped holes at O2– sites generate O- species in the TiO2 catalyst. By analyzing the photoexcited electron (Ti3+ signal) and hole signals (oxygen radical signals) of Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts under UV irradiation (blue line in Fig. S14), the hole signals were almost the same in intensity, whereas the electron signals were not observed, implying that electrons were injected into the Rh metal. Fig. 7(c) shows the valence band spectra for TiO2 ST-01, TiO2 rutile, TiO2 P25, and TiO2-B nanobelts; their valence band maximum values were 2.73 eV, 2.47 eV, 2.47 eV, and 2.52 eV, respectively. As shown in the UV–vis absorption spectra (Fig. S6), the bandgap values of TiO2 ST-01, TiO2 rutile, TiO2 P25, and TiO2-B nanobelts were estimated to be 3.30 eV, 3.06 eV, 3.30 eV, and 3.52 eV, respectively. The conduction band minimum (CBM) potential of TiO2-B nanobelts was the most negative among the other TiO2 polymorphs, which indicates that the TiO2-B nanobelts have a strong reducing ability compared to the other TiO2 materials and are expected to undergo electron injection to Rh and lead to CO2 reduction. This is consistent with the report by Wibowo et al. that a high CBM can easily reduce CO2 to CO and has high DRM activity [34]. In addition to the discussion on the electric band structure, the chemical reaction process in the photocatalytic DRM reaction should be considered. According to the assumption of the previous photocatalytic DRM reaction model [27,40], two CO molecules are generated in one CH4 and one CO2 molecule by considering the carbon balance. This assumption implies that oxygen ion transport occurs between the carbon species. Shoji et al. showed that oxygen species in SrTiO3 predominantly act as photocatalytic redox mediators in the DRM reaction, using the isotopic oxygen 18O [27]. In addition, our study using a gas-phase photoelectrochemical system showed that oxygen ions produced by the reduction of carbon dioxide were used as mediators to link redox reactions and oxidize methane [40]. Therefore, the transport process of oxygen ions may play a significant role in the catalytic activity in the DRM reaction. To investigate the mass transport process of oxygen species, we conducted a photocatalytic activity test under methane gas conditions. Here, experiments were performed on Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts and Rh/TiO2 rutile for comparison. TiO2 rutile was chosen as a control group because TiO2 ST-01 is inactive for the DRM reaction and TiO2 P25 is a complicated mixed phase of anatase and rutile. First, argon-based sole methane gas flowed under UV light irradiation, hydrogen was generated in both Rh/TiO2 rutile and Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts, while carbon monoxide gas was detected only in Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts (Fig. 8 a and d). Here, both hydrogen and carbon monoxide gases were generated, and the amount of hydrogen was larger than that of carbon monoxide (Fig. 8d), indicating that these products originated from methane. When we compared the amount of hydrogen and carbon monoxide generation, we found that hydrogen continued to be produced during light irradiation, whereas the amount of carbon monoxide produced gradually decreased and eventually became undetectable. This indicates that the oxygen species contained in the surface atomic layer of the TiO2-B nanobelts have been used. After methane gas flow, we subsequently introduced carbon dioxide in addition to methane (DRM condition), and both hydrogen and carbon monoxide were regenerated under light irradiation (Fig. 8b and e). Comparing the Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts and Rh/TiO2 rutile, it can be seen that the amount of carbon monoxide produced in both cases was larger than that of hydrogen because of the reaction of many carbon species left on the surface that could not be converted to carbon monoxide during the methane alone gas experiment. Finally, we switched the gas flowing into the reactor back to methane gas and continued to observe the products under light illumination (Fig. 8c and f) and observed a similar tendency (Fig. 8a and c). These results strongly suggest that the oxygen source for carbon monoxide production is carbon dioxide in photocatalytic DRM. The oxygen species in the catalyst mediate the reaction with the carbon species produced during the partial oxidation of methane, the ability to discharge and take up oxygen ions in the process is strongly related to the performance of the photocatalyst, and the oxygen defects inherent in TiO2-B nanobelts (confirmed in Fig. 3a) are responsible for the very high catalytic activity with stoichiometric reaction and long-term stability of Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts. Scheme 1 shows the proposed mechanism of photocatalytic DRM driven by bandgap excited carriers in Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts. As revealed by the XPS and UV–Vis data, the TiO2-B nanobelts have upper positions of CB than the pure anatase phase (TiO2 ST-01), rutile phase (TiO2 rutile), or mixed phase (TiO2 P25). For TiO2-B nanobelts with metal Rh nanoparticle junctions, during the photocatalytic DRM, photoexcited electrons in the CB of TiO2-B nanobelts transfer to the metal Rh nanoparticles and reduce carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and oxygen ions. The oxygen ions generated by the reduction of carbon dioxide are quickly incorporated into the catalyst lattice by the oxygen defects contained in the TiO2-B nanobelts, and the photoexcited holes are used for the partial oxidation of methane. This is very similar to the reaction mechanism that we proposed using a gas-phase photoelectrochemical system based on a yttria-stabilized zirconia oxygen ion conductor separator [40]. The high availability of lattice oxygen and the high re-storage capacity of Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts catalysts, as revealed by the performance test using sole methane gas, make the residual carbon after methane decomposition react with the oxygen ions generated by carbon dioxide reduction. Such oxygen ion reactivity of TiO2-B nanobelts prevents coking and yields efficient conversion of DRM over the long term. Conventional photocatalytic water splitting and/or CO2 reduction used protons as a mediator, which is different from our DRM mechanism. In the present study, we also examined the photocatalytic water splitting activities of Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts and Rh/TiO2 (rutile) to compare their DRM activities (see our supporting information, Fig. S17). Interestingly, the surface area of Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts measured by BET is larger than that of Rh/TiO2 rutile (33.8 m2 g−1 and 9.8 m2 g−1, respectively), and even though the CB is more negative, hydrogen production by photocatalytic water splitting was obviously better in Rh/TiO2 rutile than in Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts. These results also indicate that the photocatalytic DRM reaction proceeds under the different mechanism from conventional aqueous photocatalytic reactions. The present study provides a new strategic approach to utilize photon energy for methane conversion with TiO2-based photocatalysts that have not been able to show significant activity. Our Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts photocatalyst exhibited a quantum efficiency of 2.1%. In this study, we succeeded in demonstrating the high activity of TiO2-based photocatalysts, which brings the DRM closer to commercialization. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrates that the bandgap excitation process in TiO2-B nanobelts-supported Rh nanoparticle photocatalysts with a higher conduction band level and oxygen ion conductivity considerably assisted methane and carbon dioxide activation for syngas production via dry reforming of methane at very low temperatures. Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts have successfully utilized photon energy through photocatalysis to exceed the equilibrium-limited performance of using only a thermal catalysis system for syngas production in DRM. The oxygen defects found in the TiO2-B nanobelts efficiently aided to remove the residual carbon formed by the partial oxidation of methane, leading to very high durability. The conventional mediator in photocatalytic water splitting and carbon dioxide reduction is a proton. In contrast, the methane conversion reaction occurs in the gas phase, and oxygen ions function as mediators; therefore, oxygen defects, which were not originally preferred in photocatalysts, are highly effective in the present DRM reaction case. This study opens a new avenue for the construction of energy-efficient nanometal photocatalysts with inexpensive and safe TiO2-based materials to utilize solar light for the activation of commercially useful methane conversion reactions. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of methane and carbon dioxide into syngas (dry reforming of methane; DRM) has attracted attention owing to the potential to reuse greenhouse gases. Titanium dioxide (TiO2)-based photocatalysts, which have been widely commercialized owing to their high efficiency, non-toxicity, and low cost, are strongly desired in DRM. Here, we report a monoclinic-phase TiO2-B nanobelts-supported rhodium (Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts) catalyst that efficiently promotes DRM under ultraviolet light irradiation at low temperatures. Photogenerated holes in the TiO2-B nanobelts were used to oxidize methane, while the electrons were trapped in rhodium to reduce carbon dioxide. Rh/TiO2-B nanobelts exhibited considerably higher durability and activity than Rh-loaded conventional TiO2 (anatase and rutile), owing to the lattice and/or surface oxygen reactivity in TiO2-B nanobelts, which was suggested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements and photocatalytic performance tests under an atmosphere of methane alone. This study paves the path for the effective utilization of methane by constructing active TiO2-based nanometal photocatalysts.
